packageJson.name: component-page-creator
packageJson.description: An internal Gatsby plugin that creates pages from component files in src/pages
packageJson.author: Kyle Mathews <mathews.kyle@gmail.com>

packageJson.name: component-layout-creator
packageJson.description: An internal Gatsby plugin that creates pages from component files in src/layouts
packageJson.author: Kyle Mathews <mathews.kyle@gmail.com>

packageJson.name: internal-data-bridge
packageJson.description: An internal Gatsby plugin which creates data nodes from internal data
packageJson.author: Kyle Mathews <mathews.kyle@gmail.com>

packageJson.name: dev-404-page
packageJson.description: Internal plugin to add a 404 page in development with helpful information
packageJson.author: Kyle Mathews <mathews.kyle@gmail.com>

packageJson.name: prod-404
packageJson.description: Internal plugin to detect various flavors of 404 pages and ensure there's a 404.html path created as well to ensure compatability with static hosts
packageJson.author: Kyle Mathews <mathews.kyle@gmail.com>

packageJson.name: gatsby-source-filesystem
packageJson.description: Gatsby plugin which parses files within a directory for further parsing by other plugins

packageJson.name: gatsby-transformer-remark
packageJson.description: Gatsby transformer plugin for Markdown using the Remark library and ecosystem

packageJson.name: gatsby-remark-images
packageJson.description: Processes images in markdown so they can be used in the production build.

packageJson.name: gatsby-remark-responsive-iframe
packageJson.description: Make iframes in Markdown processed by Remark responsive

packageJson.name: gatsby-remark-prismjs
packageJson.description: Adds syntax highlighting to code blocks at build time using PrismJS

packageJson.name: gatsby-remark-copy-linked-files
packageJson.description: Find files which are linked to from markdown and copy them to the public directory

packageJson.name: gatsby-remark-smartypants
packageJson.description: Use retext-smartypants to auto-enhance typography of markdown

packageJson.name: gatsby-transformer-sharp
packageJson.description: Gatsby transformer plugin for images using Sharp

packageJson.name: gatsby-plugin-sharp
packageJson.description: Wrapper of the Sharp image manipulation library for Gatsby plugins

packageJson.name: gatsby-plugin-google-analytics
packageJson.description: Gatsby plugin to add google analytics onto a site

packageJson.name: gatsby-plugin-offline
packageJson.description: Gatsby plugin which sets up a site to be able to run offline

internal.content:
--- title: A Working Theory of Components date: "2017-11-27" conf: ClarityConf path: "/theory/" --- Design Systems are our current model of making sense of the intersection of front-end code and design. With the tools we have today, what is our working model of a component? How do we define them, create them, and ensure they work at scale? In this talk well discuss how our tools affect our understanding, create a checklist of factors that make a component a component, and how to implement the theory of components with the tools you have at hand.

## Overview Over the past 15 years, our understanding of the world of front end development has changed. We have been iterating constantly on our working theory of how to design and code for the web. Weve used the tools we have not just to create solutions to the problems we face, but also to create new tools. These tools arent just helping us do our job; they are _changing_ the way we can even _conceptualize_ our work. Were building on what we learned previously, filling in the gaps and unknowns. We are coming to a new understanding, with these new tools, of how to create the front end at scale: Design Systems. We want isolated components that we can reuse, styles that dont conflict, and an easy authoring experience. At a high level, we know that a component needs to be three things: 1. easy to reason about 2. context agnostic 3. independent and isolated Our theory of components should be mostly applicable regardless of our tools. What works for one project may not work for another. But when you find things that dont work, gaps in our knowledge, that doesnt mean the whole theory is broken. We are experimenting with this theory of design systems every day as we work. What we learn will add to the theory, help us move forward, and create even better tools to improve our work. Searching for new solutions might even propel us forward so far we have as many new questions as answers. As we work together today and tomorrow and in the months and years to come, keep thinking beyond todays understanding of the world, and on to tomorrows. ## Notes _Did you take notes during this talk? Share them with me and I'll share them here!_ ## Resources ### Books These books inspired the science story in my talk. _Black Holes Blues_ especially is the best book I have read in a long time. I highly recommend it! * David Baron, American Eclipse * Janna Levin, Black Hole Blues * Thomas Levenson, The Hunt for Vulcan ### Science Links * Ripples in spacetime: Science's 2016 Breakthrough of the Year, sciencemag.org * LIGO and Virgo observatories detect gravitational wave signals from black hole collision, phys.org * The most beautiful theory, economist.com * Happy Bicentennial, Mr. Le Verrier, mathouriste.eu * Jan 2, 1860, the Discovery of Planet Vulcan, oddsalon.com * Janna Levin on Black Hole Blues, brainpickings.org ### Tech Links * SUIT CSS Styling dependencies * Interview with Mark Dalgleish, didoo.net * Mark Dalgleish, First Class Styles presentation * Let There Be Peace on CSS, didoo.net

--- title: I Have No Idea What I'm Doing date: "2015-04-16" conf: Front End Design Conf, CSSConf Oakland, Converge SE path: "/tigers" --- Exploring impostor syndrome, the fine line between deceit and 'fake it til you make it,' and discovering ways we can be intentful about how we learn, challenge ourselves, and share our knowledge. ## Conferences * Front End Design Conf St. Petersburg, FL July 11, 2014 * CSSConf Oakland Oakland, CA December 9, 2014 * Converge SE Columbia, SC April 16, 2015 ## Overview We've all felt compelled to say, "oh but I'm so bad at this," lest someone think we might have something valuable to say. We've all felt that surge of inspiration, followed by frustration, sometimes to the point of being unwilling to try again. Why say you am not good at something? Doesn't being challenged matter? Is being good at something the only measure of its worth? In this talk I explore how we learn, the fine line between deceit and "fake it til you make it," and discover some ways we can be intentful about how we learn, challenge ourselves, and share our knowledge. * Be lucky * Set Goals * Work joyously * Share your doubts * Celebrate your wins * Help others ## Notes * James Brown notes from FrontEndConf 2014 * Nathaniel Deal's notes from FrontEndConf * Helen Holmes notes from CSSConfOakland * Jina Bolton's notes from CSSConfOakland * audience participation photo from CSSConfOakland ## Resources * No One Knows What the F*** Theyre Doing (or The 3 Types of Knowledge) * How Developers Stop Learning: Rise of the Expert Beginner * Dreyfus Model of Skill Acquisition * We are All Bad Programmers, Tyler Menezes * Henry Miller's Commandments of Work * On Being a Senior Engineer, John Allspaw * Kate Mats, Finding your Flow * Kate Mats, Overcoming Self Doubt * Kate Mats, Make your own Luck * It's Dangerous to Go Alone Julie Pagano * Banishing Impostor Syndrome * ALA People Skills for Web Workers * The Passion Gospel, Avdi * Programmer Levels, @oscargodson * Impostor Syndrome Tip, @bantik * @jessiheron "I drew the inside of my brain at all times" ### Credits Custom typography beautifully done for me by Jillian Adel.

frontmatter.title: I Have No Idea What I'm Doing
frontmatter.conf: Front End Design Conf, CSSConf Oakland, Converge SE
